And it's since emerged that United have offered Mbeumo a contract package that starts at £150,000 per week, with add-ons rising to £200,000 per week.

headline: Manchester United's full list of ins and outs for summer transfer window after exits confirmed
body: The summer transfer window will temporarily close for business on Tuesday evening, meaning time is running out for Manchester United to add to their squad ahead of the mid-window deadline.
As a result of the new-look FIFA Club World Cup format, the transfer window opened earlier than usual this summer on June 1.

United made a flying start to the window, confirming the signing of Wolves star Matheus Cunha just 14 hours after the shutters had been lifted. He has agreed to sign a five-year deal subject to him obtaining a visa and registration.

He is United's only new recruit so far this summer, but the club is working on a deal to sign Brentford star Bryan Mbeumo. They saw an opening offer of £55million knocked back for the Cameroonian last week.

However, United are understood to still be in talks with the Londoners and they are expected to submit a new and improved offer. It is believed Brentford are holding out for a similar fee to the £62.5m United paid to sign Cunha, although that was via a release clause.

Unless the situation develops at 100mph, United are highly unlikely to add Mbeumo to their ranks ahead of Tuesday night's 7pm deadline. However, the fact the window will open again as soon as next Monday (June 16) means that not too much time will be lost.
As far as outgoings are concerned, United have confirmed Victor Lindelof, Jonny Evans and Christian Eriksen will leave Old Trafford when their contracts expire on June 30.

United want to be proactive in the seller's market this summer and want to offload the likes of Marcus Rashford, Alejandro Garnacho, Jadon Sancho and Antony. It is important the club generates funds to bring in new arrivals.
In addition to trying to sign Mbeumo, United want to sign a striker, a midfielder and a goalkeeper. The addition of a specialist right wing-back is also yet to have been ruled out.
In: Matheus Cunha (£62.5m - Wolves).
Out: Victor Lindelof (end of contract), Jonny Evans (end of contract) and Christian Eriksen (end of contract).

headline: Ruben Amorim has already explained why Bryan Mbeumo is perfect for Manchester United
body: Manchester United head coach Ruben Amorim has already outlined his preference of having a left-footed player in the right-sided No.10 position amid the club's pursuit of Brentford star Bryan Mbeumo.

United are determined to sign the Cameroon international to bolster their attack and they saw an opening offer worth £55million turned down last week. It is understood they will submit a new and improved offer for the 25-year-old.

Mbeumo was one of the stars of the 2024/25 Premier League campaign, netting 20 goals and registering seven assists. Only Liverpool ace Mohamed Salah (47) and Newcastle United striker Alexander Isak (29) were directly involved in more goals.

Having already signed Matheus Cunha from Wolves to strengthen their attacking options, United's pursuit of Mbeumo highlights their desire to recruit players who have a proven track record in the Premier League. Cunha scored 15 league goals himself this term.

With Cunha expected to occupy the left-sided No.10 position, Mbeumo, if signed, is expected to operate from the right-sided No.10 position. United still want a centre-forward to spearhead the attack and operate between them.
Despite Amad's effectiveness from the right-sided No.10 position in the second half of the season, he has also demonstrated that he is effective from the right wing-back berth.

However, Mbeumo, in terms of being a goalscorer, is an upgrade. He has scored 38 Premier League goals over the last three seasons, with this season's return of 20 his best in the top flight in a single campaign.

Taking his goalscoring record and his profile as a left-footed player into account, he is perfect for Amorim, who admitted ahead of United's 2-0 defeat to Newcastle United at Old Trafford back in December that he wants to operate with a left-footed player on the right of the attack, after making the decision to move Amad further forward.
"I try to reinforce the team with the idea and try to use the characteristics of the players."
With that in mind, Amorim's admission about Amad being a suitable fit for the right wing-back berth in the future could pave the way for him and Mbeumo to form a solid partnership down the right.
Mbeumo is a multi-functional operator, capable of playing out wide or through the middle, meaning he would tick a lot of boxes for United. He could also be asked to operate as a No.9.

Taking Amorim's admissions about wanting a left footer in the right-sided No.10 role and Amad being a long-term option for the right wing-back spot, it is highly likely they could join forces down United's right flank. It would be an exciting combination.

headline: Manchester United's answer to their top transfer priority might be becoming clearer
body: The summer transfer window has only been open for just over a week and already Manchester United have had to change course.

After identifying Liam Delap as their top target to strengthen their attacking options, members of United's hierarchy must have breathed a collective sigh when they learnt of the England Under-21 international's decision to move to Chelsea.

Delap, who scored 12 Premier League goals in his first and only season at Ipswich Town, was available via a £30million release clause, making him an attainable target. He held talks with a cluster of suitors, including United.

As frustrating as it can be for a club to have their transfer blueprint shredded, the good news is that Delap has made his move to Stamford Bridge right at the very start of the summer, leaving United with plenty of time to explore alternative avenues.
Furthermore, is missing out on Delap as big a 'blow' as some may claim it to be? He has just one season of top flight football under his belt and is still incredibly raw at the age of 22.

After gambling on potential in 2023 with Rasmus Hojlund and again last summer with Joshua Zirkzee, United can ill-afford to take another risk on a striker this summer. They need a proven goalscorer who can come in and hit the ground running.
Right now, a handful of names are frequently cropping up on repeat. The strikers in question are Napoli's Victor Osimhen, Viktor Gyokeres of Sporting Lisbon and soon-to-be free agent Jonathan David.
Of the Premier League's elite, United, Arsenal and Liverpool are the only three in desperate need of an out-and-out striker this summer now that Chelsea have signed Delap.

Arsenal are prioritising a move for former United target and RB Leipzig striker Benjamin Sesko. The Slovakian netted 21 goals in Germany this season and he has emerged as the Gunners' preferred target to bolster the tip of their attack.
Liverpool have loosely been linked with a crop of forwards, but their current priorities are to wrap up the signings of Bournemouth left-back Milos Kerkez and Bayer Leverkusen star Florian Wirtz.

Meanwhile, despite Osimhen's move to Al-Hilal being on, off, on again and then finally off, Galatasaray are set to try their luck to re-sign the striker permanently after his productive loan spell in Turkey this season.

With Arsenal, who have also been heavily linked with Gyokeres, occupied chasing Sesko, Osimhen at the centre of a saga and David being eyed by the likes of Barcelona and Paris Saint-Germain, Gyokeres is shaping up to be the most accessible striker for United to chase.
As soon as Ruben Amorim swapped Sporting for United last November, links connecting the Swede with Old Trafford were inevitable. Naturally, they have been persistent for months.
But at a time where United desperately need a reliable goalscorer, there is a feeling developing that it may be inevitable the 27-year-old follows in in Amorim's footsteps.
It is widely reported he will be available for a fee in the region of £60m this summer, which feels relatively respectable for a player that has plundered a whopping 97 goals in the last two seasons.

He joined Sporting in July 2023 on the back of a prolific season with Coventry City. He was the best striker in England outside the Premier League in 2022/23 and he was linked with various Premier League clubs.

However, after his agent had held talks with Amorim, it was decided Sporting was the best destination for Gyokeres to take the next step in his career. That theory has been reflected in his tally of 97 goals in 102 games.

Fast, strong, aggressive and an excellent striker of the ball, Gyokeres ticks a lot of boxes. His goalscoring record in the last couple of years, for both club and country, has been astonishing and every striker ought to be judged on their record in front of goal.

If United are to fulfil their mission of signing a prolific goalscorer this summer, they have no choice but to loosen the purse strings. They have already spent £62.5m on Matheus Cunha and a similar fee could soon be spent on Bryan Mbeumo, meaning sales will be key to funding any further new arrivals.

However, failing to recruit a No.9 this summer is a non-negotiable. With Arsenal focusing on Sesko, Al-Hilal desperate to sign Osimhen and Liverpool currently focusing on other priorities, United might have a clear run at trying to attain a striker Amorim knows inside out.

headline: Bryan Mbeumo transfer could be bad news for Ruben Amorim favourite at Manchester United
body: Slowly but surely an image of how Manchester United could line up at the start of next season is developing.

Just over a week into the first stage of the summer transfer window and United have already wrapped up the signing of Wolves star Matheus Cunha. They have now set their sights on attempting to lure Brentford ace Bryan Mbeumo to Old Trafford as well.

To say United have made an ambitious start to head coach Ruben Amorim's first summer at the helm is an understatement. Cunha has arrived in M16 on the back of a 17-goal season in all competitions and Mbeumo netted 20 goals in the Premier League in 2024/25.

Identified as a top target several months ago, Cunha has arrived at Old Trafford with the task of almost certainly filling the left-sided No.10 position. If Mbeumo is successfully drafted in, it is thought he will occupy the right-sided No.10 position.

United have finished each of the last two Premier League campaigns with a negative goal difference, meaning their decision to try and bolster their attack as their first port of call this summer is a wise one.

Cunha, and possibly Mbeumo, would immediately add the goals that have been missing in previous seasons. Between them, they have plundered 56 goals between them since the beginning of the 2023/24 Premier League campaign.

In addition to adding goals to the team, Cunha and Mbeumo would also strengthen the levels of competition for places. Despite Amorim often struggling to find a consistent and productive attack this term, it was not through a lack of options.
United have a cluster of players who are capable of playing in either of the two No.10 positions: Bruno Fernandes, Kobbie Mainoo, Mason Mount, Alejandro Garnacho, Joshua Zirkzee, Cunha and Amad.

With Garnacho facing the prospect of being sold and Fernandes looking increasingly likely to be deployed as a No.8 next season amid Cunha's arrival, the size of that list will reduce, meaning Mainoo, Mount, Zirkzee, Cunha, Amad and potentially Mbeumo will all be challenging to start in the two No.10 positions.
Of course, each of those players are versatile to some degree but the majority will believe that is their best position in Amorim's 3-4-2-1 system.
If Mbeumo signs, Amad is highly likely to be installed as United's first-choice right wing-back and operate from out wide. However, Mainoo and Mount will be less assured of regular starting berths.

Mainoo has struggled to force his way into the starting XI this calendar year, with his one-minute cameo against Tottenham Hotspur in the Europa League final feeling rather telling about where he currently sits in Amorim's plans.
Meanwhile, Mount started the last four games of the season, including the Europa League final. Amorim is a massive fan of the former Chelsea man.
"I'm so happy for him," Amorim said after Mount scored twice in United's 4-1 win over Athletic Club last month. "He is such a player. He works really hard, he has quality.
"When you see that kind of guy like Mason working hard every day, eating well, having ice baths, when you have this kind of player you just want to help him."

The fact he started the final four games of the season as one of the two No.10s confirmed once and for all just how highly Amorim rates him. Injuries, however, plagued his first two seasons at the club, restricting him to just 46 appearances across all competitions.

Well-versed in a three at the back formation from his Chelsea days, it is understandable why Amorim is so fond of the 26-year-old. He is a tailor-made fit for his system and his understanding of what to do and where to be when United don't have possession is admirable.

However, if United land Mbeumo, it is hard to see where Mount fits into Amorim's first-choice starting XI. Mbeumo and Cunha would occupy the two spots reserved for the No.10s and Mount is not a central-midfielder in this system.
Competition for places is healthy and should never be frowned upon, but one of Amorim's most valued players may have to settle for a place on the bench.

headline: Viktor Gyokeres 'furious' as transfer stance shifts amid Manchester United links
body: Viktor Gyokeres' stance amid reported transfer interest from Manchester United has emerged.

United could be set for a busy summer transfer window over the next few months, having already brought Matheus Cunha to Old Trafford. United agreed to pay the £62.5million release clause in the Brazilian's contract at Wolves to complete their first signing of the summer.

Brentford forward Bryan Mbeumo is also a target for United as Ruben Amorim and Co. look ahead to next season. Mbeumo may not be the only forward who United want to bring to the club this summer, though.

Gyokeres has been linked with joining United for several months, with the rumours ramping up over the last few days. The Sporting Lisbon striker has also been mentioned as a potential target for Arsenal, Liverpool and Chelsea since the turn of the year.

A fresh update has emerged in Portuguese news outlet Record about Gyokeres' future. The report claims that the striker is not happy with the Sporting hierarchy amid continued speculation about his future.

It has been reported that Sporting are asking for a higher fee that what the club is said to have promised Gyokeres to allow the striker to leave this summer. The Sweden international has a €100million (£84million) release clause in his contract but has been reported to be available for €70million (£60million).

However, it has now been suggested that Sporting are seeking a fee closer to €80million (£67.4million). This, the report claims, has made Gyokeres "furious" after the aforementioned agreement with the club.

The report concludes by claiming that Sporting are yet to receive any bids from clubs interested in signing Gyokeres this summer. The striker enjoyed an impressive season in front of goal last term, finding the back of the net 54 times in 52 appearances and helping Sporting win the Primeira Liga title and the Taca de Portugal trophy.

headline: Tottenham forgot crucial Bryan Mbeumo detail that gives Man United transfer advantage
body: Tottenham Hotspur are considered to be prepared to go in strong to sign Brentford forward Bryan Mbeumo in the summer transfer window, right underneath the noses of Manchester United.

MEN Sport understands that United have made Mbeumo their priority now that Liam Delap is no longer a viable option. They have submitted one bid worth £55m which is believed to be below Brentford's valuation but they remain confident of getting a deal done.

Over the weekend, though, the transfer was thrown into some jeopardy when Spurs announced the sacking of Ange Postecoglou and Thomas Frank was quickly established as their preferred successor. It is understood that Tottenham were informed by Frank that he would want them to battle for Mbeumo should he be hired and Spurs agreed that this would be a good idea.
All of this sounds absolutely perfect for the north London club - the perfect plan, perhaps. However, they have somehow forgotten a crucial detail that still gives United the edge.

Mbeumo had the chance to continue working with Frank this season when United initially made a move for him. At this stage, there was no suggestion that the Dane would be leaving the club and, on the surface, Brentford was offering a brighter vision than United.

They comfortably finished above the Reds and neither club could offer the Cameroonian talisman Champions League football. And yet, Mbeumo still favoured a move to Old Trafford and gave them priority to pursue him this summer.

Clearly, the 25-year-old is not motivated by the short-term project nor does he feel like he needs to follow Frank to his next destination. Instead, he is motivated by the project at United and playing under Ruben Amorim.

This is not a case of when Antony wanted to follow Erik ten Hag from Ajax to United. Mbeumo wants to join because of the vision that Amorim is setting out for him and this is what gives the Reds a clear advantage over Spurs.

headline: Tottenham prepare Man United target Bryan Mbeumo welcome gift amid transfer tussle
body: Tottenham Hotspur could have the perfect welcome gift for Manchester United target Bryan Mbeumo if the Brentford talisman chooses to move across London this summer.

In recent weeks, Mbeumo has emerged as a top target for United after they missed out on Liam Delap. MEN Sport understands that United submitted a £55m bid for the winger but it is believed this has been rejected with Brentford thought to be valuing him at a similar price to Matheus Cunha who was bought for £62.5m by the Reds.

Mbeumo is understood to favour a move to United this summer and is giving the Reds priority to negotiate with him. Last week, the transfer was thrown into some slight jeopardy after reports emerged that Tottenham could enter the race to sign him.

This started after Spurs sacked manager Ange Postecoglou and listed Bees boss Thomas Frank as their top candidate to replace him. It was claimed that the Dane informed Tottenham chairman Daniel Levy that he would insist the club targets Mbeumo in the transfer window and the owner was on board with the idea.

If Tottenham were to complete this deal for Mbeumo, they already have the perfect welcome gift for him. For his national team Cameroon, the 25-year-old wears the number 20 having worn number 19 for much of his time at Brentford.

Spurs' current No.20, Fraser Forster, was confirmed to be leaving north London this summer when his contract expires meaning that shirt number would be available for the forward if he wished to take it. While United would not be able to offer Mbeumo the No.20 as it is currently occupied by Diogo Dalot, they could potentially go one better.

The No.19 at Old Trafford is currently vacant having last been worn by Raphael Varane during the 2023/24 season. While his final decision is unlikely to be made based on available squad numbers, Mbeumo can at least rest easy that either his ideal shirt numbers are available at whichever club he moves to.

headline: Rasmus Hojlund to Inter Milan transfer update as 'deal confirmed' amid Manchester United exit links
body: Inter Milan have confirmed the appointment of a new manager amid interest in Manchester United striker Rasmus Hojlund.

The United star's future has been the subject of intense speculation since the 2024/25 season came to an end. Hojlund scored just 10 goals for United last season, with just four of those coming in the Premier League.
The striker did find the back of the net six times on United's way to reaching the Europa League final. Since the season finished, though, Hojlund has been linked with a move away from Old Trafford.
Amid the speculation around Hojlund's future, Inter have confirmed the appointment of Cristian Chivu as the club's new manager.

The announcement comes after the departure of former boss Simone Inzaghi, who guided the Italian giants to the Champions League final before taking the job as manager of Al-Hilal in the Saudi Pro League.
Now that Chivu has been confirmed as the new Inter manager, it's only going to be a matter of time before a decision is made on whether or not the club will pursue a deal for Hojlund.
United signed the striker from Atalanta for £72million back in 2023, and he has since gone on to score 26 goals during his time at Old Trafford.

United could be set to embark on a major summer rebuild, particularly in the forward line. Matheus Cunha has already been signed from Wolves in a £62.5million deal, while Brentford star Bryan Mbeumo and Sporting Lisbon striker Viktor Gyokeres continue to be linked with a move this summer.

headline: Victor Osimhen has made Man United feelings clear after dream transfer admission
body: Victor Osimhen has already expressed his desire to one day play in the Premier League amid suggestions that a potential move to Manchester United put him off the idea of joining Al Hilal.

It has been widely reported that Osimhen was offered a lucrative contract to move to Al Hilal this summer ahead of their Club World Cup campaign. However on Sunday, it came to light that the Nigerian had rejected a move to the Saudi Pro League.

According to Tuttosport, the reasoning behind this decision was that Osimhen had become aware of the chances that a move to United or Arsenal could be possible this summer. With the hope of a transfer to the Premier League still on, it is thought that Osimhen passed up the opportunity to join Al Hilal.

Those who have been studying Osimhen's career for a while would be able to explain that this theory presented on Monday makes sense. During his time at Ligue 1 club Lille, the striker spoke fondly of his desire to play in the Premier League and admitted he had already sought advice from a former United player about the division.
"Of course, one day I’d like to play for a big club in England," Osimhen told The Independent. "I've spoken to Odion [Ighalo] about it.
"He gave me very good advice, he’s a legend and a big brother. My goal is to play at one of the biggest clubs in the world but now I’m very happy in Lille.
"My priority is to play a lot of games. Signing for a big club and being on the bench is not exciting for me."
With his career at a crossroads and his stay at Napoli seemingly impossible to continue, perhaps Osimhen will take this opportunity to push for his dream deal.

headline: Bryan Mbeumo has four things Manchester United and Ruben Amorim need
body: Having already secured Matheus Cunha's signature, some Manchester United supporters must have felt the need to pinch themselves after learning of Bryan Mbeumo's desire to move to Old Trafford.

Just over 24 hours after United announced the £62.5million arrival of Cunha from Wolves, it emerged Mbeumo had informed Brentford's hierarchy of his eagerness to move to M16. United have since held talks with the Londoners and had a £55m offer turned down last week.

However, discussions remain ongoing and United are expected to lodge a new and improved bid for the 25-year-old, who netted 20 Premier League goals for the Bees this season. It is thought Brentford will demand a similar fee to what the Reds paid for Cunha.
Understandably, the prospect of Mbeumo being added to United's attack has increased the excitement levels among the fans.
With that said, here are four reasons why signing Mbeumo would make such perfect sense for United and head coach Ruben Amorim:

After turning to Italy for each of their last two attacking signings, it is nice to see United looking closer to home this summer. Cunha scored 15 goals in the league this season and Mbeumo netted 20, meaning they are well established in England's top flight.

Since the beginning of the 2023/24 campaign, the duo have netted 56 Premier League goals between them, meaning they have established consistent records. Mbeumo, who has predominantly played out wide during his time at Brentford, has scored a respectable 42 goals in four Premier League seasons since the Bees were promoted in 2021.

United last signed out-and-out attackers from Premier League counterparts on permanent deals in the 2017/18 season, swooping for Romelu Lukaku and Alexis Sanchez. At this particular juncture, United are much wiser to go for ready-made talents that are already proven in England.

United's attack has lacked a multi-functional operator in recent seasons, meaning the prospect of Mbeumo arriving from west London would add another string to their bow. Traditionally a right-winger, he can also play through the middle as a No.9.

In Amorim's 3-4-2-1 system, the expectation is Mbeumo would operate as the right-sided No.10, operating close to the centre-forward United so desperately crave. However, the Cameroonian is also capable of playing as a striker himself, meaning he could operate centrally if asked to do so by Amorim.
Furthermore, his power, pace and aggression mean he could play on the right flank as a wing-back. He is also renowned for his defensive work and willingness to track back.

With the exception of Amad, United do not currently have another left-footed player who can realistically operate as one of the two No.10s, making the club's pursuit of Mbeumo all the more understandable. The Brentford man is renowned for drifting inside from the right.

Amorim, last December, outlined his personal preference to have a left-footed player in the right-sided No.10 role, meaning it quickly became easy to understand why Amad was often tasked with playing in that role after initially being deployed at right wing-back after Amorim's appointment in November.

Also hinting that Amad's long-term position could be at wing-back, it makes all the more sense for United to pursue Mbeumo's signature. He is a perfect fit for the role Amorim so desperately wants to strengthen.

Most importantly, Mbeumo will add goals to United's blunt attack. The Reds scored just 44 goals in the Premier League this season, meaning they only managed to score 24 more as a collective than Mbeumo did on his own.

Mbeumo has been a regular source of goals and assists in Brentford's attack since their promotion from the Championship four years ago, contributing 28 assists in addition to his 42 goals. Marcus Rashford (131) and Bruno Fernandes (113) are the only current United players with more direct goal involvements in the Premier League than Mbeumo (70).
With that in mind, signing Mbeumo is a no-brainer. United need to inject goals, creativity and flair into their attack.

headline: Manchester United set for unexpected £2m transfer windfall after copying Man City tactic
body: Manchester United could be in line for a surprise cash injection this summer thanks to former youngster Maxi Oyedele.

According to Italian journalist and transfer guru Fabrizio Romano, Oyedele, who left United last summer to join Polish outfit Legia Warsaw, is attracting interest from a collection of clubs from across Europe.
He has reported that Werder Bremen, PSV Eindhoven, Anderlecht, Club Brugge and two unnamed Championship clubs have all expressed interest in his signature after a promising debut season in Poland.

It has been reported that Oyedele, 20, 'will leave' Legia this summer and is available via a release clause worth €6million (£5.05m at the current exchange rate). The defensive-midfielder made 24 appearances in his debut season at Legia, helping them win the Polish Cup for a 21st time.

News of reported interest in his signature from elsewhere will be of interest to United. As a result of becoming more proactive in the seller's market last summer, the Reds inserted various clauses into a collection of outgoing deals, including the one that saw Oyedele move to Poland.

According to Romano, the sell-on clause means United will inherit 40 per cent of the fee Legia bank from any potential sale of the midfielder. It means United, who were probably not anticipating Oyedele would develop at the speed he has, could bank just north of £2m.

Oyedele, as proven with the current level of interest being expressed in his signature, enjoyed a strong first season in Poland. His achievements included making his debut for the national team at senior level and making five appearances in the Europa Conference League, including two quarter-final starts against Chelsea.

As a result of United's smart thinking, any funds they bank via sell-on clauses they included in deals from previous windows will go towards assisting their efforts in the quest to remain compliant with the profit and sustainability rules (PSR).

United's cross-city neighbours, Manchester City, have often been the masters of such scenarios in previous years, regularly offloading young talent with sell-on clauses attached to any future moves so they can receive money on the back of any future success.
United also included a buy-back option in the deal that saw Oyedele move to Legia, meaning they covered all bases. Sell-on clauses were also included in other deals United completed last summer.

headline: Man United make Viktor Gyokeres 'contact' as fresh transfer update issued on striker
body: Manchester United have reportedly made contact over a potential deal for Sporting striker Viktor Gyokeres.

The Swedish international has risen to prominence as one of Europe's leading strikers in recent years, boasting an impressive tally of 97 goals in 102 matches since his transfer from Coventry City to Liga Portugal in July 2023.

Sporting's top scorer this season has made a significant impact in the Portuguese top-flight, netting 39 goals and providing eight assists in 33 appearances. The 26-year-old has been a pivotal player in Rui Borges' squad, driving Sporting to another league title.

And journalist Fabrizio Romano, who specialises in transfers, has claimed via GiveMeSport that officials from Old Trafford have made contact to 'understand how the situation was developing' for the Swedish striker.
It is claimed that Champions League football was 'probably going to facilitate the deal for United.' However, the Reds' absence from that competition means a potential deal has been complicated.
The report adds that until Gyokeres' situation 'gets advanced' with another club, United will keep being informed. It is claimed they are in contact with his camp.

Gyokeres has been strongly linked with a move to Old Trafford since the appointment of former head coach Ruben Amorim at M16 in November. The Reds are in dire need of a consistent goal scorer this summer, having only netted 42 times in the Premier League.
It is unclear whether missing out on Delap will lead United to turn towards Gyokeres instead.

headline: Man United 'eye' Viktor Gyokeres free agent transfer alternative as club 'hijacks' move
body: Manchester United completed their first piece of summer transfer business when they announced the signing of Matheus Cunha from Wolverhampton Wanderers last Sunday. The Brazilian has made the £62.5million move and has penned a five-year contract, with the option of a further 12 months.

While United coughed up a sizeable fee to secure Cunha's services, more are expected to follow. Ruben Amorim's side are chasing a move for Brentford's Bryan Mbeumo and have seen a £55m bid rejected. Mbeumo is believed to have made it his preference to make the move to Old Trafford this summer.

Elsewhere, there is going to be a prime focus to get players out of the door. Marcus Rashford, Antony and Jadon Sanchoare three players that have been tipped to leave Old Trafford. Rasmus Hojlund, meanwhile, has confirmed that he doesn't expect to leave United, despite talk of a move to Inter Milan.
Tottenham are prepared to hijack Manchester United's proposed transfer for Bryan Mbeumo, despite the player preferring a move to Old Trafford, according to The Sun.
He snubbed interest from Arsenal and Newcastle United, both competing in next season's Champions League, in favour of choosing to join Ruben Amorim's United.
However, Spurs are keen to make a late move and attempt to tempt Mbeumo to team up with Thomas Frank, who appears to be the favourite to replace Ange Postecoglou.
Mbeumo scored 20 goals and provided seven assists in 38 Premier League appearances under Frank for Brentford this season and Tottenham hope to bring him to north London.

MEN says: Manchester United must ensure that Tottenham don't hijack a move for Bryan Mbeumo. He is one of the most sought-after players in the Premier League and he could flourish under Ruben Amorim next season.

Plus, the fact that Mbeumo has chosen a move to United over Arsenal and Newcastle would give me confidence that he is committed to the project at Old Trafford and they need to get a deal done for him as soon as possible.
Manchester United are considering a shock move for Everton forward Dominic Calvert-Lewin when his contract expires this summer, according to Fichajes.
The 28-year-old's deal is up at the end of the June and Everton are not expected to offer the 11-time England international a new contract, meaning he can leave on a free transfer.
Ruben Amorim is keen to strengthen his squad and add a new centre forward, but Profit and Sustainability (PSR) constraints mean that United need to careful with their spending.
And Calvert-Lewin has opened up as a potential bargain, considering he would arrive as a free agent. The former Sheffield United man has scored 57 goals across his Premier League career.
MEN says: It's clear Manchester United need to sign a new No.9 this summer. The Reds scored just 44 goals in 38 matches in the Premier League last season, and that's nowhere near enough.
Viktor Gyokeres has been identified as a top target having impressed in Portugal for Sporting CP, but United might not have the funds to bring in the £60million-rated frontman this summer.
It does mean that United may have to look for a cheaper alternative, and Dominic Calvert-Lewin is someone that has been linked, considering that he is going to be a free agent at the end of the June.

However, United should avoid the temptation of moving for Calvert-Lewin due to his damning injury record and mixed form at Everton across the last couple of years. Instead, United would be better off looking at a move for Jamie Vardy, 38, after he confirmed his departure from Leicester City in April.

headline: Victor Osimhen has just sent Man United transfer message they can no longer ignore
body: Manchester United find themselves in an unenviable scenario in the summer transfer window which they hoped they would avoid.

Since losing to Tottenham in the Europa League final, United have moved into a position whereby they need to compromise on their plans for the summer. Had they qualified for the Champions League, the market suddenly becomes open for the Reds and they become a more enticing proposition.

Now, having lost that final, United are in a situation where they are having to rely on reputation and players wishing to join the cause, to rebuild the club. This is how they managed to sign Matheus Cunha and it could be how Bryan Mbeumo decides he will move to Old Trafford.

However, the club is unlikely to find it this easy to complete a move for a centre-forward this summer. We all know that there is an abundance of No.10s in world football but there is now a severe lack of No.9s.

This is by no means a new phenomenon - no club has ever wanted to let go a No.9 who knows where the back of the net is. These days, United cannot even use their wealth to sign the next best striker like they did with Dimitar Berbatov and Robin van Persie.

Therefore, when a player like Victor Osimhen is as good as telling you to make a bid for him, United would be crazy to ignore that. Journalists Ben Jacobs and Fabrizio Romano both reported on Sunday evening that Osimhen has decided to reject a lucrative offer from Al Hilal this summer.

Despite the Saudi Pro League club agreeing a £63m transfer with Napoli, Osimhen decided not to agree personal terms with the Middle East club. This rejection of Al Hilal is a huge signal that the striker wants to remain in Europe, competing at the highest level.

If he was solely looking to make exceptional amounts of money, he would have accepted Al Hilal's offer. If Osimhen wanted move to Galatasaray, that deal could have been struck by now as the Turkish club have been trying desperately to convince him to make his stay permanent.
Now, it is up to United to put forward an alternative to him. Beyond the two clubs mentioned above, there are a lack of options currently on the table for Osimhen.

Yes, United cannot offer the Champions League but they can offer him the opportunity to play for one of the world's biggest clubs in the most competitive top league on the planet. Surely it is worth at least attempting to sign a player that has scored 37 goals this season.

headline: Premier League's first black referee Uriah Rennie dies aged 65
body: Uriah Rennie, the Premier League's first black referee, has passed away at the age of 65.
Born in Jamaica, Rennie was raised in Sheffield and went on to officiate more than 300 top-flight matches, beginning with his inaugural game between Derby and Wimbledon in August 1997.

The sad news was confirmed by the Sheffield and Hallamshire County Football Association on X: "We are deeply saddened to learn of the passing of our former chair and trailblazing referee, Uriah Rennie.

"Uriah made history as the Premier League's first black referee, officiating over 300 top-flight matches between 1997 and 2008. He broke down barriers, shaped our football community and inspired generations to come.
"Our thoughts are with Uriah's family and friends at this difficult time."

Earlier this year, Rennie spoke out about having to learn to walk again after he was left paralysed from the waist down during a holiday in Turkey. "I thought I had just slept funny on a sun lounger, I was hoping to go paragliding but because of my backache I couldn't go," Rennie told the BBC.
"By the end of the holiday I couldn't sleep a wink from the pain, and by the time I got home I could barely walk. I spent a month laid on my back and another four months sitting in bed.
"They kept me in hospital until February, they found a nodule pushing on my spine and it was a rare neurological condition so it's not something they can operate on."
Tributes have poured out to Rennie after his passing was confirmed.

In a post on social media, Sheffield Wednesday wrote: "Sheffield Wednesday are deeply saddened to learn of the passing of pioneering referee Uriah Rennie. Our thoughts are with his family and friends at this incredibly sad time."

In a post on social media, Championship club Sheffield United said: "Sheffield United are saddened to learn of the passing of popular and trailblazing referee Uriah Rennie. Our thoughts are with his friends and family at this time."
Former Liverpool and Nottingham Forest striker Stan Collymore, meanwhile, has described Rennie as a "pioneer, trailblazer and a bloody good ref".
He wrote: "Incredibly sad to hear of the passing of referee Uriah Rennie. A pioneer, trailblazer and a bloody good ref. Rest in peace, Ref."

headline: Alejandro Garnacho shares summer update amid Man United transfer uncertainty
body: Manchester United winger Alejandro Garnacho has confirmed he is in Italy amid uncertainty surrounding his future at Old Trafford.

Garnacho's time at United looked to be running out on the day of the Europa League final. He began pre-match by posting pictures of himself scoring at Wembley in the Reds' last final before it emerged that he would not be starting against Tottenham Hotspur.

Post-match, he then described United's season as having been 's***' and that he was disappointed at only playing 20 minutes against Spurs. Shortly afterwards, MEN Sport reported that Garnacho had been informed that he should look for another club next season.

This weekend, Garnacho's future was back under the spotlight once again when reports emerged that the Argentine had come to an agreement that he should seek an exit from Old Trafford this summer. With the post-season tour in Asia out of the way, the 20-year-old is now in a position to explore his options.

Chelsea have been heavily linked with the winger and speculation grew in January when his agents were spotted at Stamford Bridge. It later emerged that they visited on their own accord, rather than through an invite.

Serie A champions Napoli had a bid rejected in the winter for Garnacho by United. Antonio Conte is thought to be a big admirer of the youngster and sees him as a replacement for Khvicha Kvaratskhelia who they lost to PSG in January.

Journalist Fabrizio Romano has reported that three unnamed Premier League clubs are keen on Garnacho and there is also interest in Italy for his services. Coincidentally or not, Garnacho has now shared on Instagram that he is in Italy, specifically Rome, as he rests ahead of the start of pre-season.

The forward shared a picture of himself outside the Colosseum in Rome which could fuel speculation that he favours a move to Serie A this summer. Garnacho may feel that Napoli would be a good fit for him considering how Conte and the club have rejuvenated the career of Scott McTominay this season.
The summer transfer window will close briefly on June 10 before reopening on June 16 and closing once more on September 1.

headline: Matheus Cunha to Man United £62.5m transfer concern as Ruben Amorim told how to unleash new star
body: Matheus Cunha is the first signing of a huge summer at Manchester United.

Everyone knows how important recruitment will be at Old Trafford over the next few months as the Reds look to recover from their lowest-ever Premier League finish. The absence of European football at M16 will only make that task harder.

But the early signs are promising and optimism is building after United's swift start to the summer window. There is hope that Ruben Amorim's side can put a dismal campaign behind them and truly begin their rebuild under the former Sporting head coach.

One man who has followed Cunha's career closely in England is Wolves correspondent for the Express and Star, Liam Keen. He explains why United may have been so eager to wrap up a £62.5million deal for the Brazilian.

"Cunha is a supremely talented footballer," Keen said. "He arrived in the January of 2023 when Julen Lopetegui was just taking over and Wolves were struggling down the bottom, and obviously he was part of that that turnaround in keeping the club up at the time and he didn't do loads in the six months of the second half of that season, he was sort of settling in a little bit.

"Lopetegui was playing him as a number nine on occasions, and very clearly he wasn't a number nine. We saw his real breakthrough under Gary O'Neil in the following season, who quickly realised that Cunha is not a number nine. He's someone to play off the left more than anything, but to occupy those number 10 positions in and around the forward or the number nine, and as a footballer, he took his game to a whole new level.
"Last season and the first season with Gary O'Neill it was his two best seasons in his career. He's a very good goal scorer, glides with the football.

"For those reasons, he was able to push Wolves on a little bit under O'Neil in that first season. They were going to Europe for quite a while, until it slipped away in the back end of the campaign, and that was with him having a bad injury as well."
Keen also reveals how Wolves have managed to get the best out of Cunha since his arrival at Molineux two and a half years ago.
"I think having a focal point number nine," he explains. "That helps Cunha because he has someone to play off and feed off someone.
"Also, I think down that left side having a wing back who is underlapping him, giving him options, opening space for him. I think those options really helped to get the most out of his game.

"Equally he is quite keen to drop deep, pick the ball up in sometimes difficult areas and he's got the ability to sort of turn very quickly in tight spaces and as soon as he's got a little bit of space in front of him, he's turned one player, very often he was able to open the game up for for for Wolves.

"Going forward, I think the way United play and the sort of positions he'll occupy, I think that would be really important for them. He's able to turn defence into attack very quickly despite obviously not being a defensive player."
Keen has shared his belief that Cunha's level is currently above that shown by Amorim's men. He does, however, claim that his personality is not the easiest to deal with.

"Without a doubt, everyone recognises he's a top player who can play at the very top in the Premier League," Keen admits. "No disrespect to Man United, but we know they're not exactly the beast they once were at the moment.

"I think from a talent perspective, he can definitely be playing at a higher level than where they're currently at. In terms of the size of a club, because United's a massive club, of course, I think he's in the right place, going somewhere where he's going to be really important and having that added pressure.

"The issues he's got off the field, he's struggled to deal with pressure at times at Wolves. He wasn't massively liked around the place as a person, as an individual. Of course, plenty of teammates got on with him. There were a lot of Brazilians, and lots of Portuguese-speaking people, but in general, he was someone who would kick off very quickly. He would fall out with people around the place and with fans.

"He's someone that's got a lot of shortcomings and was universally, not particularly liked by a lot of people, but as a player, he did the business. That's the balance you've got to find at United because he's going to have so many more eyes on him at a club like United. So much more media attention, so much more attention in general that he's going to have to try and find a way to deal with that."

headline: Transfer rumour power ranking: Man Utd used by CL winner but forward offers boost
body: Manchester United might be rubbish, but two things remain true: they are still a bigger pull than Spurs, and they endure as the favourite bargaining tool for agents across Europe…
With so much transfer talk doing the rounds, we’re here through the summer to sift through the bullsh*t and highlight the whispers that might have some substance.
Each day we’re ranking the top 20 rumours involving Premier League clubs, the higher the link, the more likely we feel they are to becoming done deals.
So we start with the tittle-tattle…

20) 🆕 Gianluigi Donnarumma – PSG to Manchester United
Donnarumma sees Old Trafford as a ‘tempting destination’, does he? Or is it that the Italy keeper has been in contract talks with PSG for months and he isn’t getting what he wants so his representatives are pulling the oldest trick in the agents’ book? You decide.

19) 🆕 Alejandro Garnacho – Manchester United to Arsenal
Garnacho is finished at United – but they still have to get rid of him. The winger would prefer to stay in the Premier League, apparently, with Chelsea and Arsenal having asked. But why would either do a deal on United’s terms? Chelsea have their sights set elsewhere and Arsenal have cast their net wide too. The Gunners might take Garnacho, but most likely on loan if others higher on their list opt against moving to the Emirates.

18) 🆕 Heung-min Son – Tottenham Hotspur to Al-Hilal
The Saudi Arabian club are desperate to make a statement signing and the Spurs captain could be perfect. He’s out of contract next summer as well.

16) 🆕 Jack Grealish – Manchester City to Newcastle
This is a move we could really get on board with. The story goes that Newcastle want to take Grealish on loan with an obligation to buy for something like £67million. Which sounds like a deal City would be daft to turn down given Pep is clearly done with Grealish. Do it, Toon.

MORE ON THE SUMMER 2025 TRANSFER WINDOW
👉 Every Premier League transfer and release confirmed in the summer of 2025
👉 Twenty biggest transfers in the world in 2025 summer transfer window
👉 Wirtz next? The last five times every Premier League club broke transfer record

15) Luis Diaz – Liverpool to Barcelona
Our reading on this: Barca want Diaz, who would be happy to move to the Nou Camp. Liverpool might be interested in a deal, but only on their terms. Which Barca won’t meet, and Diaz knows it so he won’t kick up a fuss – yet. If this is going to happen, someone needs to change tack.

14) Joao Pedro – Brighton to Newcastle
The Seagulls forward is intent on leaving Brighton to take the next step but apparently, wherever he goes, he wants to be the first choice. Fine, but he won’t get that at Newcastle while Alexander Isak is around. For how long will that be? That is the more pressing concern for Newcastle fans.

13) 🔼 Viktor Gyokeres – Sporting to Manchester United
With Arsenal going cold on Gyokeres, there were plenty of reports that the Swede is open to a move to Old Trafford after all. Which may be a consequence of the queue at Sporting’s door being more sparse than many of us expected. But if United can get it done, it would be a step on the road to regaining some credibility.

12) Benjamin Sesko – RB Leipzig to Arsenal
The Slovenia striker has overtaken Gyokeres as the favourite to fill the gaping chasm in the centre of Arsenal’s attack. After much deliberation, it seems the Gunners favour a deal with RB Leipzig over whatever they could get out of Sporting. After talks at the back end of last week, the wheels seem to be in motion.

11) Martin Zubimendi – Real Sociedad to Arsenal
This one got the ‘Here we go’ treatment over a month ago but then it all went a bit quiet. Initial reports suggested there is no reason for Arsenal fans to panic, with agreements in place between all parties. But here come Real Madrid.

10) 🔼 Mike Maignan – AC Milan to Chelsea
Chelsea have made it clear to Milan they are keen on the France keeper, but they won’t pay the £25million the Rossoneri want for a player entering the final year of his contract. Chelsea are said to be offering £10million for now, so there is some talking to be done. But whatever they pay up, it will be worth it.

9) 🔼 Bryan Mbeumo – Brentford to Manchester United
Tottenham’s renewed interest threatened to scupper United’s hopes of landing Mbeumo but even the prospect of following Thomas Frank to Spurs isn’t deterring the forward from pursuing a move to Old Trafford. He’ll get his way ‘soon’, apparently.

8) 🔼 Kevin De Bruyne – Manchester City to Napoli
There was a hitch around image rights last week but, apparently, that has been resolved and De Bruyne is set to sign a two-year contract to fulfil his dream of playing with Scott McTominay.

7) Florian Wirtz – Bayer Leverkusen to Liverpool
Liverpool have improved on their opening bid of £109million by returning with an extra £4million. Leverkusen, as they should, are still haggling but the Reds are close. They’re hardly likely to walk away over a few euros and leave Wirtz hanging. The player will be looking for progress this week now there’s no international distraction.
👉 Five reasons why Florian Wirtz may not actually be a good signing for Liverpool

6) 🔼 Jamie Gittens – Borussia Dortmund to Chelsea
Chelsea’s first offer of £30million was rejected, with Dortmund wanting £40million, and the Germans know the Blues can be squeezed as the pre-Club World Cup deadline looms. A seven-year contract is reportedly on the table for the winger.

5) Milos Kerkez – Bournemouth to Liverpool
Word last week was it’s happening. For around £40million. Which represents decent business for both sides. Things have gone a little quiet since while Liverpool pursue Wirtz but seemingly there is nothing or Reds to worry about here.

4) Kepa Arrizabalaga – Chelsea to Arsenal
This one is moving quick, apparently, with Arsenal aware that the world’s most expensive goalkeeper will cost them just £5million. Interesting one, this. Kepa recovered some credibility on loan at Bournemouth last season and won’t be going to Arsenal just to play second fiddle to David Raya. Bring on the Gunners goalie wars!

3) 🔼 Jobe Bellingham – Sunderland to Borussia Dortmund
A very on-brand deal has been agreed to make Jude’s little bro the second-most expensive player in Dortmund’s history. Jobe is apparently in Germany to drop his trousers and cough for the Dortmund doc and, all being well, he’ll be unveiled in the coming days.

2) 🔼 Rayan Cherki – Lyon to Manchester City
City have agreements with Cherki and Lyon and they are in a hurry so expect this to be one of three deals confirmed this week.

1) Tijjani Reijnders – AC Milan to Manchester City
It’s pretty much done, apparently. City have agreed a fee of £46million to sign the midfielder, with Milan hoping to net another £12.5million in add-ons. Reijnders and Rodri in midfield? City won’t be sh*t again next season.

headline: Every Premier League transfer and release confirmed in the summer of 2025
body: The Premier League transfer window opened on June 1 and then closes on June 10 for six days before re-opening on Monday June 16 until Deadline Day on Monday September 1.
